search.query:
| `incident_review` | eval end = if("$time_2.latest$"=="now", "now()", "$time_2.latest$") | eval start = if(match("$time_2.earliest$","^-"),relative_time(now(), "$time_2.earliest$"), "$time_2.earliest$") | where _time>start AND _time<end | rename status_label as default_status | search $status$ | table time rule_name comment rule_id status owner owner_realname reviewer reviewer_realname | eval long_name="$selectedRule$" | eval long_name = replace(long_name,"^[^-]+-\s+",""), long_name = replace(long_name,"\s+-\s+Rule$", "")
| sort rule_name rule_id time | rename rule_name as search_name | where LIKE(search_name,long_name)

html.p: You can use this dashboard to see all of the enabled correlation searches at a glance, see their comments if they exist, and jump to the Incident Review dashboard. The panel sub-titles will tell you what actions clicking a row will trigger.

Start by clicking a rule youâ€™d like to investigate. After clicking a rule, three new panels will appear, your selected correlation search, a count of comments in incidents, and the details of incident events. If you click on the name of the search in the selected search panel, you will be taken to Incident Review, where you will see the name of the search you selected and the date will also already be set based on your last view. If you click on a row in one of the two Incident history-related panels the events will be filtered to a specific rule_id. To investigate a different correlation search, simply return to the top, adjust your parameters if desired, and click on a new rule name.
The Incident Event panels will only populate if there are notable history events. E.g, A status change, comment, assigned user etc.
